Anno primo RICHARDI III.

Statutes made at Weftminflet in the first year of the reigri of King Richard III. and in the year of our Lord 1483.

RICHARD by the grace of God King of England, and of France, and lord of Ireland, the third after the conqueft; to the honour of God, and of holy churchy and for the common wealth of bis realm of England, at his first parliament holdert at Wcftminfter, the three and twentieth day of January, in the first fear of his reign, by the advice and ajfent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and at the. requeft of the commons of the /aid realm of England, fummoned to the /aid parliament, by the authority of the fame parliament, hath ordained and eftablijhed, for the quietnefs of bis peoplej certain ftatutes and ordinances in manner following•

All ails made by hr against Ceftuy que ufe Jhall be good against him, bis heirs and feoffees in truft.

FOrafmuch as by privy and Unknown feoffments, great un~ feveral furety, trouble, cofts, and grievous vexations daily grow inconve-among the King’s fubjefts, infomuch that no man that buyeth nieneies of any lands, tenement s, rents, fervices, or other hereditaments, nor women that have jointures or dowers in any lands, tenements, or Godbolt 306. other hereditaments, nor mens laft wills to be performed, nor pi. 4.17. leafes for term of life, or of years, nor annuities granted to any 1 Anderf. 333 person or perfons for their fervices for term of their lives or 1	I33‘

CAP. II.

*Ihe fubjeSs of this realm Jhall not be charged by any bene* volence, &c.

ii Co. 119.	/ l ^HE King remembering how the commons of this his realm, by new

A and unlawful inventions, and inordinate covetife, againjl the law of this realm, have been put to great thraldom and importable charges and exactions, and in efpecial by a new impofition called a Benevolence, whereby divers years the fubjefts and commons of this land, againjl their wills and freedoms, have paid great fums ofmoney to their almo/l utter defruition : (2) For divers and many worjhip* ful men of this realm, by occafion thereof, were compelled by neceffity to break up their houjholds, and to live in great penury and wretched-nefs, their debts unpaid, and their children unpreferred, and fuch Tnemorials as they had ordained to be done for the wealth of their fouls were anentized and annulled, to the great difpleafure of God, and The fubje&s the dejlruftion of this realm : (3) Therefore the King will it be f,hls r^lm ordained, by the advice and aflent of the lords spiritual and charged with temPora*a and the commons, of this prefent parliament af-any benevo- fembled, and by the authority of the fame. That his fubjedfcs, lences, &c. and the commonalty of this his realm, from henceforth in no ijCar.aiiat.i. wife be charged by none fuch charge, exadtion, or impofi-c‘4*	tion, called a benevolence, nor by fuch like charge; (4) and that

fuch exadttons, called benevolences, before this time taken, be taken for no example to make fuch or any like charge of any of his faid fubjedfcs of this realm hereafter, but it lhall be damned and adnulled for ever.

CAP. IV.

Of what credit and eft ate tbofe jurors muft be which Jhall be impanelled in the fheriff's turn.

FOrafmuch as divers great inconveniencies and perjuries do daily nH. 7. c. if.

happen in divers /hires of England by untrue verdifts given in inquijitions and enquiries before jheriffs in their turnsy by perjons of no Jubjtance nor behaviour, not dreading God nor the world's Jhamey by reafon whereof divers and many of the King's lieges of divers parts of England, py exciting and procuring of their evil witters, be xvrongfutty indifled> and other that ought of right to be indifted by fuch excitation and procuring, oftentimes be jpared, contrary to common right and to good conscience.	(2) In efchewing whereof, be

it ordained by the King our sovereign Lord, by the advice of the lords spiritual and temporal, ana commons in this prefent parliament aflembled, and by authority of the fame, That no bailiff nor other officer from henceforth return or impanel any fuch person in any Ihire of England, to be taken or put in or upon any fuch inquiry in any of the faid turns, but fuch as be of good name and fame, and having lands and tenements of freehold within the fame (hires to the yearly value of xxs. at Ofwhatcre-the lead, or elfe lands and tenements hoiden by cuftom of dit and eiUte manor, commonly called copyhold, within the faid (hires, to thoJ*jl1ro™ , the yearly value of xxvi. s. viii. d. over all charges at the lead : j}J^j j^.lc

CAP. VI.

TheJlatute of 17 Edward IV. cap. 2. rebearfed and made perpetual, viz. That in every court of pipowders the plaintiff or bis attorney Jhall be fworny &c.

PRayen the commons in this prefent parliament affembledy That where in a Jlatute made in the feventeenth year of the reign of King Edward the Fourth* it was ordained among other, That where divers fairs have been holden and kept in divers places within this realmy fome by prefcription allowed before jujlices in eyrey and fame by the grant of your noble progenitors and predecefforsy and to every of the fame fairs is of right pertaining a court of pipowdersy to minijler therein due jujlice in that party; (2) in Which court it hath ever b{en accujlomedy That every person coming to fuch fairSy should have lawful remedy of aU manner contrails, trefpaffesy covenantSy debts, and other deeds made or done within any of the faid fairs during the time of the faid fairSy within the jurijdiftion of the famty and to be tried by merchants being at the farrie fairs; (3) which courts in thefe days have been mifufed by Jlewardsy bailiffsy commiffarieSy and other mini/lerSy holding and ruling the faid courts of the Jaid fairs for their Jmgular profity holding plea by piaintSy as well contrary debts, tref-paffeSy and other deeds done and made out of the time of the faid fairs or fairy and jurifdiftion of the fame, whereof in troth they have no jurifdiftiony furmifing the contrary debtsy trefpaffesy covenantSy or other deeds to be done within the time of the fairsy and within the jurifdiftion of the fame fairsy where\ in troth they were not fo.	(4}

CAP. IX.

In what fort Italian merchants may fell mercbandifes. Several reftraints of aliens.

ITEM, becaufe our faid fivereign Urd the King, upon petition The griev-made to him in his faid parliament by the commons ^England, ances done by hath conceived and underjlood, That whereas merchants firangers	mcrchant*

the nation of Italy, as Venetians, Genoefe, Florentines, Apuli- ^ng and ans, Cicilians, Lucaners, Cataloins, and other of the fame.na- hi* realm. tion, in great number do inhabit and keep houfes, as well in the city ^/“London, as in other cities and boroughs within this his realm, and take warehoufes and cellars, and therein put their wares and mer~ chandsfis which they bring into this faid realm, (3) and them in the faid cellars and warehoufes deceitfully do pack, mingle* and keep the fame, till fuch time the prices thereof be greatly enhanced, for their great lucre, and the fame mercbandifes and wares they then fill to all

manner

manner people, as well within the ports where they bring the fend wares and merchandifeSy as to other divers and many places within this reabty as well by retail as otherwife; (4) and alfo do bay in the Jaid ports and other places, at their own liberty, the commodities of this realmy and fell the fame again at their pleafure within the famey as commonly and freely as any of the King’s liege people dothy (5) and do not employ a great part of the money coming thereof upon the commodities of this realmy but make it over the fea by exenange to divers other countrieSy to the King’s great damage in lofs of his cuf-tomSy and to the great impoverijbing of his faid fubjeftSy of whom they Jbould buy the commodities of this realm :

II. III.	Alfo the [aid merchants of Italy do buy in divers places within this realm a great quantity of wool and woolen clothy and other mer~ chandifes of the King’s fubjeftSy and part thereof they fell again to the fame fubjefts and other within this realm y to their mojl advantagey and much of the faid wools they do deliver to clothmakerSy thereof to make cloth at their pleafure.

IV.	Moreovery a great number of artificers and other Jlrangersy not born under the King’s obeyfancey do daily refort and repair to the city ^London, and to other citiesy boroughsy and towns of the faid realmy and much more than they were wont to do in times pa fly (2) and inhabit by themfelves in the laid realm with their wivesy childreny and houjholiy and will not take upon them any laborious occupationf as going to plough and carty and other like bufmefsy but ufe the making of cloth and other handicrafts and eafy occupationSy (3) and bring and convey y from the parts beyond the feay great fubjlance of wares and merchandifes to fairs and marketSy and all other places of this realm at their pleafure, and there fell the famey as well by retail as otherwifey as freely as any of the King’s fubjefts ufe to doy to the great damage and impoverijbment of the King’s faid fubjeftSy (4) and will in no wife fuffer nor take any of the King’s faid fubjefts to work with themy but they take only into their fervice people born in their own countrieSy whereby the King’s faid fubjeftSy for lack of occupation fall into idlcnefsy and be thievesy beggarSy vagabonds, and people of vicious livingy to the great perturbance both of the King and of all his realm ; (5) and when the merchant Sy artificer Sy and firangers before rehearfeety have gained within this realmy by buying and fellingy or by fuch eafy occupations and handicraftSy greatfubjlance of goods y with the fame fubjlance they go out of this[aid realm to fuch parts beyond the fea as them lileth bcjly and there fpend the fame goods oftentimes among the King’s adverfaries and enemiesy to the great damage of our Jove-reign lord the King and his fubjeftSy and impoverijbment of this realmy and the commons of the fame; and fo by occafion of the premiffeSy the fubjlance of the inhabitants in the faid cities y boroughsy and townSy now late hath fallen, and daily doth fall, into great poverty and de~

twixt the buyer and the feller contrary to this ordinance ii> any 18 h# 6. c.17.

manner notwithstanding.	uHf 7. c!*.

CAP. XIV.

Accmptants for difmes of the clergy not chargeable to anfwer other mens fuits in the exchequer.

ITEM, Whereas the clergy of the provinces of Canterbuiy and York, have before this time divers times granted to the King's progenitors, in their convocations, Difmes to be levied of their goods and poffefftons, and after that they do appear before the barons of the King's exchequer, and the names of the collectors for the fame grant be certified in the faid exchequer, when the Jaid collectors do appear before the barons of the exchequer, and enter into their account for the faid Diftnes, that then the faid collectors be often charged, vexed,, and troubled with bills put by other per-fens against them, for other caufes and matters than touching the find account, and by occafion thereof oftentimes they fall to great poverty, and caufeth the faid account to be two or three yean banging and the Difmes	contented, to the Kings great damage,

and the faid collectors alfo:

IL ft is therefore ordained and eftablilhed by the King, his lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons, in this prefent parliament aflembled, That from henceforth if any Difme, or any part of a Difmi, be granted by the province of either of the faid clergies, to the King our lovereign lord, or to his heirs, that after the faid certificate returned into the exchequer for the Difme or part of the Difme, and of the names of the collectors for the gathering of the fame Difme, that if the faid collectors Accountants come by procels before the faid barons of the exchequer, and ford/m,,dar# enter in their account, that they shall not be bound to anfwer anfvw'other to the faid bill or bills there put against them, by reafon of the mens fuits iq faid entry in their account, for any manner caufe, but only for the exche-the matter touching the faid account.	clucr•

III.	Provided always. That if the faid accomptant be fued in any other court by writ, bill, or plaint, that then he shall take do privilege of the (aid exchequer, by reafon .of the faid account for any fuit, as before is rehearfed.

CAP. XV.

A refumption of all grants, and eftates of lands, isle, made to Elizabeth Grey late Queen of England.

Thus End the Statutes made in the Reign of King Richard the Third.

The iecond parliament, holden in the third year of King Hen. VII.

tfbe authority of the court offar-chamber. Where one in-quejt Jhall enquire of the concealment of another. A coroner's duty after a murder committed. Ajuftice of peace Jhall certify his recognifances, &c.

thing by the law for their office doing, which oft-time hath

CAP. VII.

A certificate Jhall be made of goods brought into one port and removed to another. One man Jhall not enter goods in the name of another.

ITEM, The King our sovereign lord, by the advice and aftent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons afiembled in the faid parliament, and by authority of the fame, hath ordained and ena&ed, That every merchant, as well denizen as ftranger, which lhall bring from henceforth any manner of goods into any port within this realm by way of merchandife, and there do enter the faid goods or merch&ndifes in the books of the cuftomers of the faid port where the goods and merchandifes shall first come to, and the King’s duty thereof, the faid cuftomers contented, or therefore with him agreed, and afterward that done, will convey or carry the fame goods or merchandifes from thence in any other port within the faid realm: (2) that then the owner of the faid goods and merchandifes,'his fa<ftor or attorney, shall bring from the cuftomers of the port where the faid goods or merchandifes be fo entered, a certificate under the fame cuftomers feals, directed to the cuftomers of the port whereto the faid goods or merchandifes fl\all be conveyed or carried, making mention within the fame certificate, as well of the natural colour, length, and value of all merchandifes, fo entered, ufed to be meafured with eln or yard, as of the. natural weight, content or valure of all manner of other merchandifes, uied to be weighed or valured : (3) and that the fame certificate fo made be delivered to the faid cuftomers, before the faid goods be difeharged, fo that they may fee whether the nature, colour or length, valure, content or weight of the fame, do agree within the faid certificate, fo that the lung be not deceived of his cuftoms and fubfidies thereof due. CAP. IX.

Freemen of London may carry their wares to any fairs or

markets.

HU MBLY Jhewen andpraytn unto your Highnefs, your true and faithful commons of this your realm of England, That where the citizens and freemen of the city of London have sefed out of time of mind to go, carry, and lede their merchandife arid ware unto all fairs and markets at their liberty out of the faid city ; now of late time the mayor, aldermen, and citizens of the city of London, have made and enacted an ordinance within the fame city, upon a great pain, that no man that is a freeman or citizen of the faid city, fhall go or come to any fair or market, out of the fame city of London, with any manner of ware or merchandife to fell or to barter, to  Gbogle	,his

this intent, that all buyers and merchants Jhotdd refort to the jaid city to buy their ware and merchaiidifes of thefaid citizens and freemen of London aforefaid, becaufe of their lingular lucre and avail; which ordinance, if it Jbould hold as is before expreffed, Jhall be to the utter deftruftion of all otherfairs and markets within this your realm, which God defend, for there be many fairs for the common weal of your faid liege people, as at SaJifbury, Briftol, Oxford, Cambridge, Nottingham, Ely, Coventry, and at many other places where lords fpi-ritual and temporal, abbots, priors, knights, efquires, gentlemen, and your faid commons of every county hath their common refort, to buy and purvey many things that be good and profitable, as ornaments of holy church, chalice, books, veflments, and other ornaments of holy church aforefaid, and alfo for houfehold, as viftualfor the time of Lent, and other fluff, as linnen cloth, woolen cloth, brafs, pewter, beading, ofmonde, iron, flax, and wax, and many other neceffary things, the which might not be forborn among your faid liege people; but, by the faid ordinance, every man willing to buy any of the premijfes,Jhall be courted to come to the faid city ^London, to their importable cofls and charges, which, if the faid aft fbould endure, Jhall grow great hurt and prejudice to the common weal of this your realm, and Jhall caufe many pernicious ftrifes and debates between your faid liege people, and the faid mayor, aldermen, and citizens in time to come, by the making of the faid ordinance, the which is thought may not continue and ftand with good charity, the premijfes confidered; wherefore it may pleafe your laid Highnefs mojl noble and abundant grace, in confideration of the hurt likely to grow of and by the premijfes, that it may be enaftea:

No cloth Jhall be tranfported until it be barbed, rowed, and

Jhorn.

7 Ed. 4. c. 3. ITEM, Where in the faid parliament it was /hewed by Jhearmen, X fullers, and other artificers, that Jbould live and obtain their needy fujlentation by mean of drapery made and draped within this realm, as well throughout the fame realm, as within the city of London, that where in a Jlatute made the fcventh year of the reign of King Edward the Fourth, among other it is contained. That no perfon, denizen ne flranger, Jbould carry, or do to be carried to any parties beyond the fca, any woolen yarn or cloth unfulled, but that the woolen yam to be made in this realm Jbould be woven in the fame; (2) and alfo all cloth in the fame made Jbould be fulled and fully wrought within this realm, before that any of the fame should be had or carried out of this realm, upon pain offorfeiture of the very valure of fuch yam not weaved, and cloth not fulled, had or carried out of this realm\

(3)	the one half of the forfeiture to be levied to the ufe of the King, and the other half to him or them that should efpy, or make proof of any fuch yarn not woven, or cloth not fulled, carried to any place beyond the fea.

II. And forafmuch as in the faid fatute of King Edward there is no exprefs mention made, that the faid cloths should be rowed and Jhorn afore that they be carried and conveyed out of this realm, whereby the faid poor commons of the crafts aforefaid might be fet in laborer and

CAP. XIV.

Confpiring to deftrqy the King, or any lord or counfellor, or great officer, Jhall be felony.

ITEM, Forafmuch as by quarrels made to fuch as have been in great authority, office, and of council with Kings of this realm, hath enfued the dejlruftion of the Kings, and the undoing of this realm; f 2) fo as it hath appeared evidently, when comparing of the death of fuch as were of the King's true fubjefts was had, the dejlruftion of the prince was imagined thereby, and for the mojl part it hath grown and been occafioned by envy and malice of the King's own houjholdfervants, as ntnv of late fuch a thing was likely to have enfued\ (3) andforfo-much as by the law of this land, if aftual deeds be not had, there is no remedy for fuch falfe compaffmgs, imaginations, and confederacies had againjl any lord, or any of the King's council, or any of the King's great officers in his houjhold, as feward, treafurcr, and comptroller, and fo great inconveniencies might enfue if fuch ungodly demeaning should not beJlraitly punijhed before that aftual deed were done: (4) therefore it is ordained by the King, the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons, of the faid parliament aflembled, and by authority of the fame. That from henceforward the Reward, treafurer, and comptroller of the King’s houfe for the time be-

The third parliament, holden in the fourth year of the reign of King Hen. VII. Anno ,

1487.

TO the worjhip of God and holy churchy and for the common weal and profit of this realm of England, our Jovereign lord Henry by the grace of God King ^England and France, and lord of Ireland, the feventh after the conqueft, at his parliament holden at Weftminfter the thirteenth day of January, in the fourth year of his reign, by the advice and ajfent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons, in the faid parliament ajfembled, and by authority of the fame, hath dene to be made, ordained, and ejlablijhed divers Jlatutes and ordinances in form as followeth.

CAP. I.

Commiffions of fewers shall be made into all the parts of this realm, and to the marches of Calais, Gyien, and Hammes, during twenty five years.

CAP. II.

Allaying of gold and filver, melting, felling, and marking the

fame.

ITEM, Whereas it was of old time ufed, and continued till now of late years, that there was for the weal of the King and the realm, finers and parters of gold andfilver by fire and water, under a rule and order belonging unto the mints of London, Calais, Canterbury,



39

1487.J	Anno	quarto	Henrici	VII.

York and Durham, and in ether places where mints been holden, and at the goldfmiths hall in London, to fine and part all gold and fiber belonging and needful for the faid mints and fellowjhip of gold-fmiths, for the amendment of money and plate of the realm, that every thing might be reformed to the right Jlandard, as well in money as plate, to the leafs coft, for the weal of the King's noblemen of the land, and common people: (2) but fo it is now, that fuch finers and parters of gold and fiber by fire and water., dwelling abroad in every place of this realm out of the rules aforefaid, and buy gilt fiber from the mints, changes, and goldfmiths, and part and fine it as is afore faid, and for the mofi part of the fiber fo fined, they do allay it in divers manners, and fell it at their pleafures to every man of what efiate or degree Jo-ever be be, that will buy of them, to make fuch works as pleqjetb the buyers ; (3) therefore men can get no fine fiber when they need it for their money, for the amendment of money and plate, as hath been in times pa ft; wherefore it caufeth money and plate in dbers places of the realm to be made worfe in finenefs than it fbould be, as it appeareth evidently in dbers places, to the great hurt of the King's noblemen of the land, and common people: (4) wherefore the King our sovereign lord, by the aflent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and of the Allaying of commons, in the faid parliament aflembled, and by authority of gold and fiU the lame, hath ordained, enadted, and eftablifhed. That no finer .vcr* of gold and Over, nor parter of the fame by fire or water, from henceforth allay any fine filver or gold, ne none fell in any other wife, ne to any person or perfons, but only to the officers of mints, changes, and goldfmiths within this realm, for augmentation and amending of coin and plate, as is aforefaid j (5) and that the mailers of mints, changes, and goldfmiths, for all fuch fine cold or filver coming to them, to anfwer the value as it is worth, according as it is now and hath been in ancient time ac-cuftomed after the rate of finenefs: (6) ne that no finer nor finers, parter nor parters, fell to no perfon, neither to one nor to other, any manner of filver into mafs molten and allayed, upon pain of forfeiture of the fame, the King thereof to nave one half, and the finder that can prove, and will fue for it in the King’s exchequer, the other half. (7) and if any finer or finers, parter or parters of gold and filver, either by fire or water, allay or fell any manner fine gold or filver, otherwife than it is or- 5 darned in this adl, he or they to lofe the value of the fame gold or filver fo allayed or fold 5 the King to have the one half, and the finder that can prove it, and will fue for it in the King’s exchequer, the other half, (8) Alfo all fuch fine filver as shall be parted and fined as is aforefaid, that it be made fo fine, that it may bear twelve penny weight of allay in a pound weight, and yet it be as good as fterlmg, and rather better than worfe; (9) A finer of gold and that eveiy finer put his feveral mark upon fiich fine filver, and fiber to bear witnels of the fame to be true, as is afore faid, upon the muft put his pain of the value found contrary to be forfeit; the King thereof mar upon to have the one half, and the finder that can prove it, and will fue for it in the exchequer, the other half. CAP. XIII,

Clergy Jhall be allowed but once. A convifi person Jball be marked with the letters M or T. A provtfion for them which be within orders.

ITEM, Whereas upon truft of the privilege of the churchy divers Clerp fliall perfons lettered have been the more bold to commit murder, rape, ^^owcdbut robbery, theft, and all other mifehievous deeds, becaufe they have been Hob.'1*8,194. continually admitted to the benefit of the clergy as oft as they did offend in any of the premiffes; (2) in avoiding Juch prefumptuous bolanefs, it is ena&ed, ordained, and eftablilhed by the authority of this prefent parliament, That every perfon, not being within orders, which once hath been admitted to the benefit of his clergy, eftfoons arraigned of any fuch offence, be not admitted to have the benefit or privilege of his clergy : (3) And that every person A person con-lo convi&ed for murder, to be marked with an M upon the braun of the left thumb ; and if he be for any other felony, the fame person to be marked with a T in the fame place of the or x. thumb, and thofe marks to be made by the gaoler openly in the Raft. pla. f. 56. court before the judge, before that fuch person be delivered to Co* bt. 50. the ordinary. (4) Provided alway, if any person at the fecond Coron* time of afking his clergy, becaufe he is within orders, hath if Hyperion not then and there ready his letters of his orders, or a certificate in orders ask of his ordinary witnelling the fame, that then the juftices,	he

CAP. XIV.

Sealing of writings touching the earldom of March.

ITEM, Where afore in the time of King Edward the Fourth, all feoffments, gifts, grants, dernfes, prefentments, nominations, releafes, warrants, and confirmations, made to any person or perfons, of any cajlles, honours, manors, lands, and tenements, or other hereditaments, or advantages, parcel, or pertaining to the earldom of March, or pertaining to any manors, lands, tenements, or other hereditaments in demefne, or reverfion, parcel, or pertaining to the faid earldom of March, were made and pafftd under a fpecialfeal, named the feal of the marches, whereby is grown great vexation, trouble,and deceit of the fubjefts of the King our sovereign lord : (2) Wherefore it All writings is enacted by the authority of this prefent parliament. That all of any pa«*l • feoffments, gifts, grants, demifes, prefentments, nominations, ofMarch and all other writings whereto fealing is requifite, to be made shall be under after the feaft of the purification of our Lady, in the fifth year of the great feal. the reign of our sovereign lord that now is, of any parcel of the faid earldom, be had, done, and made by the King our faid sovereign lofd, under the broad feal of his chancery, as it is ufed in all other things concerning the crown, by the courfe of the common law, and by none other feal.

CAP. XV.

The mayor of London and bis fuccejfors, Jhall have the like confervation and authority in all the iffues, breaches, and ground overflown, as far as the water ebbeth and fiowetb, grown out of the river Thames, as touching the punifh-ments for ufing unlawful nets and engines, as he, had within the faid river.

ITEM, where the mayor of the city of London, for the time being, is confervator, having the confervation of the water and river ofThameSjfrom the bridge 0/* Staines, unto the waters ofY en-dalloft/Medway; it is fo that within few years, by tempefl of weather and great abundance of waters in the faid river of Thames, divers breaches, iffues and creeks, have been and grown out of the faid river of Thames, and by the fame divers paflures, meadows, and grounds of divers perfons been drowned and overflown: in which breaches tjfues and creeks, and ground drowned, the fry and brood of fijb for the mofl part refletb, and in the fame place the faid fry and brood in great multitude daily is taken by the faid pjhers there, with unlawful engines and nets for bait of eels ana cods, and aUb for the feeding of their hogs, to the utter deflrufliontf the faid fry and brood, without a remedy the rather be provided: The King our faid fbvereign lord by the advice of the lords spiritual and temporal, and at the prayers of the commons in the hud parliament af-fembled, and by authority of the fame, hath ordained, ftablidled, and enaCted, That the mayor of London, and his fucceffors mayors for the time being, have the confervation and rule, and like authority in every of the faid breaches, ifiues, and creeks, and ground fo drowned and overflown, as far as the water ebbeth and floweth, as touching the punition for ufing of unlawful nets and other unlawful engines in fifhing, like as he and his predecefTors have or hath in the fame water and river of Thames, within the bounds afore rehearfed: and to do all other like correction and punifliment there concerning the reformation and redrefs of unlawful nets and engines, as he and his predeceffort have ufed and ought to ufe in the faid river of Thames. Provided alway. That the mayor of London, or his fucceflors mayors for the time being, have not the confervation nor rule nor authority in any of the faid breaches, ifliies, creeks and grounds fo drowned ana overflown within the King’s ground, or being within any franchifcs of any person or perfons fpiritual and temporal, as touching the punition for ufing of unlawful nets and other unlawful engines in fifhing, nor to do any correction or punifh-ment there concerning the reformation and redrefs of unlawful nets and engines, as the faid mayor and his fucceffors have ufed and ought to ufe in the faid river of Thames.

CAP. XVII.

The charges arid benefit of the heir of Ceftui que ufe.

ITEM, That where adions popular in divers cafes have been ordained by many good a Sis andfiatutes afore this time madeyfor the reformation of extortions, maintenances, opprefftons, injuries, exactions , and wrongs ufed and committed within this realm y (2) which aSltons been very penal to all mifdoers and offenders in fuch adions condemned\ and much profitable as well to the King, as to every of his fubjeCts that them will fue and maintain, if the fame actions fo fued and commenced might be truly purfued without covin or col-lufion. Statutes made at Wejlminftery Anno 11 Hen. VII? and Anno Dom. j 494.

THE King our sovereign lord Henry tie Seventh after the con-quejly by the grace of God King ^England and ^/'France, and lord of Ireland, at hit Parliament holden at Weftminfter the fourteenth day of October, in the eleventh year of his reign, to the honour of God and holy church, and for the common profit of the realm, by the aff ent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons, in the laid parliament ajfembkd, and by authority of the faid parliament, hath done to be made certain (latutes and ordinances, in manner and form following.

CAP. I.

None that Jhall attend upon the King and do him true fervia Jhall be attainted, or forfeit any thing.

THE King cur sovereign lord, calling to his remembrance the duty of allegiance of his fubjefts of this his realm, and that they by reafon of the Janie are bound to ferve their prince and sovereign lord for the time being, in his wars, for the defence of him, and the land, against every rebellion, power, and might, reared againjl him, and with him to enter and abide in fervice in battle, if cafe fo require ; (2) and that for the fame fervice what fortune ever fall by chance in the fame battle againjl the mind and wtU of the prince fas in this land feme time pajjed hath been feen) that it is not teafondble,



55

1494*] Anno undecimo Henrici VIL

but againfl all laws, reafon> and good confcience, that the faid fub~ jefis going with their sovereign lord in wars, attending upon him in his terfon, or being in other blaces by bis commandment, within this land> or without,	Jbould	lofe	or forfeit for doing their true

duty andfervice of allegiance: (3) it be therefore ordained, enacted, and eftablifned by the King our sovereign lord, by the advice and aflent of the lords lpiritual and temporal, and the commons in this prefent parliament aflembled, and by authority of the feme. That from henceforth no manner of per- Noperfontbat fon or perfons, whatsoever he or they be, that attend upon the fl»u attend King and sovereign lord of this land for the time being, in his	.

perfon, and do him true and faithful fervice of allegiance in the bimtrue fer-lame, or be in other places by Ids commandment in his wars, vice, (ball within this land or without, that for the faid deed, and true he sptaioted duty of allegiance he or they be in no wife convift or attaint of ^ramv high treason, ne of other offences for that caufe, by aft of par- Jthcr ^ofence. liament, or otherwife by any procefs of law, whereby he or any of them fhall lofe or forfeit life, lands, tenements, rents, poilef&ons, hereditaments, goods, chattels, or any other things; but to be for that deed jrnd fervice utterly difeharged of any vexation, trouble, or lofs. (±) And if any aft or afts, or q-ther procefs of the law hereafter thereupon for the fame happen to be made, contrary to this ordinance, that then that aft or afts, or other proceffes of the law, whatsoever they fhall be, ftand, and be utterly void. (5) Provided alway. That no person or perfons fhall take any benefit or advantage by this aft, which fhall hereafter decline from his or their faid allegiance.

CAP. n.

CAP. XIV.

What cuftoms aliens made denizens Jhall fay for their mer~

chandifes.

TTZHERE the King our sovereign lord is greatly deceived in bis V V cufims and fubfidies by merchants andftrangers* fuch as the King our sovereign sera hath granted by his letters patents to be denizens * and to pay no other cujloms ne fubfidies for their merchandife inward and outward but as a denizen* under colour whereof they cudom not only their own merchandife under the form aforefaid* but alfo they colourably enter into the cufiomers books the merchandife of other jlrangers* calling and faying the faid goods of other merchants to be the goods of them fo made denizens, to the, great Ufs and defraud of the King our sovereign lord: (2) wherefore be it ena&ed, by the King our sovereign lord, the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons, of this prefent parliament afiembled, and by authority of the fame. That all merchant (hungers and other, that be made denizens by the King’s letters patents, or otherwife, pay from henceforth fuch cuftoms knd fubfidies for their goods and merchandife inward and outward, as they (hould have paid, if fuch letters patents and grants had never to them been made.

Entering of plaints in county courts* examining ofJheriffs* execution of precepts* viewing of eftreats* and gathering of them.

(14) and furthermore. That then the faid bailiffs shall forfeit for every default unto our sovereign lord the King xl. s. (16) and to be attaint and convift thereof by like examination of the juftices of peace, or any of them, as before is rehearfed. (17) And that the fame (heriffs, under-ftieriffs, (hire-clerks, and their deputies for the time being, shall make no eftreats to levy the faid (heriffs amerciaments, until fuch time that two juftices of peace, whereof one shall be of the £>uorum9 hath had the view and overlight of their books; (18) and that the eftreats be indented betwixt the faid juftices of peace, and the faid (heriffs and under-ftieriffs, and fealed with their feals, the one part to remain with the faid juftices, and the other part with the faid (heriffs, or under-ftieriffs, to the intent they may underlland if any deceit be, or untrue demeaning in them, in making of their books ; (19) and that thofe perfons which shall be gatherers of the fame amerciaments, as bailiffs, or other officers, be fwom by the faid juftices, that they take no more money than is forfeited and contained in the eftreats, fealed with the feals of the faid juftices of peace, upon the fame pain of forfeiture as before is rehearfed; thereof the fame gatherers to be convidf by examination of the faid juftices of peace, or one of them, as before is rehearfed. (20) Provided, alway. That the faid juftices of peace shall be appointed and named at the general feffions after the feaft of St. Michael the archangel, by him that is Cujtos Rotukrum of the faid counties, or elfe by the eldeft of the Quorum in his abfence, to have the overfight and control-ment of the faid (heriffs, under-ftieriffs, and lhire-clerks, and and other of the faid officers, and of the faid (heriffs amerciaments: (21) and the faid juftices of peace, upon fuggeftion, or information of the party fo grieved, shall make like pro-cefs/as in an action of trefpafs, against the faid (heriffs, under-ftieriffs, or (hire-clerks, and other the forefaid officers mifde-meaning, as before is rehearfed, for to appear before them to anfwer to the faid fuggeftion or information.

CAP. XVII.

The forfeiture for taking of pheafants or partridges, or the eggs of hawks or fwans.

Tbe forfeiture of him which goeth not in person with the King in bis wars, when be is in perfon.

CAP. VII.

Of murder.

WHERE abominable and wilful prepenfed murders be by the law of God and of natural reafon forbidden, and are to be efehew« ed; yet not the leys, many and divers unreafonable and detejlable perfons, lacking grace, wilfully commit murder, to the high difplea-jure of God» and contrary to all the laws abovesaid, (2) and moreover againfi their natural and obliged duty, wilfully commit prepenfed murder, in Jlaying their majler, or their immediate fovereign, under whom he or they be, or ewe obedience, in tmjl to efehew the peril and Vol. IV. CAP. VI.

Pewterers walking.

TO the King our sovereign lord, and to the noble lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this prefent parliament af-fembled, humbly and lamentably /hewn and complain unto your moft a-bundant grace, your humble fubjefis the pewterers and brafiers of your cities of LjQn&onand York, and of all other places of this your realm. CAP. XV.

CAP. XIV.

An act for fearebing of unlawful oils.

PR A YEN your Highnefs, the commons in this prefent parliament affembled, That whereas divers manner of oils being brought into this realm, as well into the city of London, as to divers other places within this fame {calm, which be daily ufed and mintftered as well for man's fujienance and comfort, as for neceffaries for draping of woolen cloths, apd for other divers neceffaries ufed for the weal of your fubjeSls; and for lack of good overfight, fearch, and correction of fuch oilss many fimple perfons (buyers of the faid oils to fell afterward) falfely and deceivabfy by crafty means do mix and alter the fame oils from theirformer nature and goodnefs, to the great /#//, jeopardy, danger, and deceit of yourfubjeSls: wherefore be it by your highnefs, by the advice *nd afjent of your lords spiritual and temporal, and of your commons, in this prefent parliament aflembled, and by authority of the fame, ordained, ena&ed, and efta-blifhed. CAP. IV.

An aSl far avoiding deceits in worfteds.

PRAYEN the commons in this prefent parliament ajfembledy That whereas worfteds which been truly madey Jhom, dyed and calan-dred, as of old time, hath been accuflomed to be madey Jbomy dyedy and calanaredy have been one bf the gocdlieft merebandife and greateft commodity of this realmy and not onfy worn within this re*bny hut dlforhuch worn and ufed in other realms ; (2) andfo it is that now of late divers ft rangers beyond the fea have taken upon them to dry colander worjteds with gumsy Msy and prejfesy fo that a coarfe piece of worftedy not being pa/l the value of xxvi.s. viii.d. is and Ihall be made} by their faid gumsy oils md prejfosy to fbew like to the value of xl. s. or better; (3) and if the fame worfted fo dry calandredy taketb any wet incontinent it will Jhew footty and fotd> and ever after conti-hui ftilifiuly and will not endure, to the great deceit and hurt of the wearers thereof and lofs of the faid commodity; and for the fond deceit sy and faljenefsy the faid dry calandring is fcorned and abhorred in the parts beyond the feayfo that no person do ne /hall ufe in thofe parts any fuch worfteds to dry calander; (4) and alfo now of late the faid ftrangers called Dry Calanders art come into this realmy and hen within the fame ufe the faid dry calandring of worfted^ and of the great hurt of the faid common weal and commodity of this realm aforejaid:

CAP. VI.

An a$ for the remitting prisoners with their indictments to the places where the crimes were committed.

> into the counties where the fame murthers or felonies have been committed and done* (3J and to command all juftices of gaol-delivery, juftices of peace, and all other juftices and commiffioners, and eveiy of them, to proceed and determine upon all the aforefaid bodies and indi&ments fo removed, after the courfe of the common law, in fuch manner as the fame juftices of gaol-dcjivery, juftices of peace, and other com-miflioners, or any of them might or fhould have done, if the faid prisoners or indi&ments had never been brought into the laid King’s bench, -

jin aS concerning the making of certain woolen cloths in the county of DcvQn.

CAP. IX.

An ail to avoid deceits in making of woolen cloths.

FOR the deceitful draping and making of woolen cloths, made and draped within this realm, and alfo for mea-furing in the fale of the fame, our sovereign lord the King, by the advice of the lords spiritual and temporal, and of the commons, in this prefent parliament affembled, and by the authority of the lame, hath ordained, eftablifhed, and enadted divers ordinances and ftatutes for the true making and draping of fuch woolen cloths, and for meafuring in fale the true con-The weight of tcnt of the fame in manner and form following: (2) Firft, ecTto break** "That the wool which shall be delivered for or by the clothier kemb, c*rd] t0 any person or perfons for breaking, kembing, carding. (3) And that the wool and yam breaker or kember to deliver again to the fame clothier the fame thedoAier t0 wo°* *° ^ro*cen anc* kembed, and the carder and fpinner to deliver again to the fiud clothier yarn of the fame wool, by the fame even, juft, and true poife and weight (the wafte thereof excepted) without any part thereof concealing, or any more oil, water, or other thing put thereunto deceivably, (4) upon the pain to forfeit to the lord of the leet within the precinft whereof fuch default is done, for every fuch default xij df upon due proof of fuch deceit afore, arid by the diferetion of the mayor, bailiff, or other head officer of the city, boroygh, or town where the deceit shall appear, the fame mayor, bailiff, or head officer calling to him luch perfons as shall (eem to hint convenient for the proof of fuch deceit.

Provided alfo, That it shall be lawful for and to every the faid ftrangers bom out of the King’s obeifance, being a houfholder, to have and retain as well all and every fuch Grangers bom out of the King’s obeifance, being the time of this parliament with him retained as a journeyman, as to have and retain every fuch ftranger being born out of the King’s obeifance, being apprentice with him the time of this parliament, this adt notwithstanding. (2) This to endure to the laft day of the next parliament.

CAP. IV.

What cuftoms and impoftions EngKftunen /warn to foreign

princes Jh all pay.

PRAYEN the commons in this prefent parliament, That where many and divers perfons, being the King's fubjefts naturally born within this his realm, have withdrawn themfehes out of the fame realm, and tranfported themfehes, with their wives, children, and goods, into Holland, Zealand, Brabant, Flanders, and into other countries of foreign princes, and there be fworii to the obeifance of the princes and lords of the countries where they be now inhabited, makings there great buildings r and be contributaries to all manner of charges, as the jubjefts of thofe countries be; and thus they maintain, as much as ih tbeftt is, the cities, boroughs, and towns of thofe countries, and many more of the King's fubjefts intend to do the fame, if remedy therein be not provided: (2) which fubjefts born in England, not-withjtanding that they thus ejlratige themfehes from the King's cbei-fance, vet they occupy here in all the ports, havens, and creeks, cities, boroughs, and towns ^/"England, as freely, and as free in cujlom and fubfiiy, as the King's fubjefts do occupy, arri not only for themfehes, but alfo coburably for Dther fir angers, their friends and partners, and alfo make themfehes quit and exempt from all charges within this realm, in prejudice and decay of the cities, towns, and boroughs of England; (3) and as for beyond the fea, they will obey to none authority granted to the Englifh nation by the King's Highnefs and his noble progenitors under the great feal 0/England, and by authority of parliament, but they give themfetves over to the proieftion and defence of thofe outward princes, to whom they be fuuom fubjefts; and by thefe manner of perfons much coin is conveyed out of the land:

By old cuftom no cleric of the chancery might marry, but only the clerk of the crown.

The fix clerks of the chancer may marry, and enjoy their offices.

Rep. 5EI.C.8. &i Jac.i.c.21.

Anno x\v. & xv. Henrici VI1L [1522-3.

CAP. vin.

Tie marriage of the fix clerks allowed, &c.

N moft humble wife befeeeben your higbnefs, your true and faithful Jubjefts, and daily fervants, the fix clerks of your high court of chancery, That whereat of old time accujlomed hath been ufed in the (ibid court, that all manner of clerks ana mmfters of the fame court, writing to the great feal, jhould be unmarried (except only the deri of the crown) fo that as well the curfitors, and other clerks, as the fix clerks of the faid chancery, were by the fame cuftom refrained from marriage, whereby all thofe that contrary to the fame did marry, were no longer fuffered to write in the faid chancery, not only to their great hinderance, lofing thereby the benefit of their long Jludy, and tedious labours and pains in youth taken in the faid court, Hut alfo to the great decay of the true courfe of the faid court.

II.	And forafmuch as now the faid cuftom taketh no place nor ujage9 but only in the office of the faid fix clerks, but that it is permitted and fuffered for maintenance of the faid courfe, that as well the faid cur-fttors, as the other clerks aforefaid, men and do take wives, and marry at their liberty\ after the laws of holy church, and of long time have fo done, without interruption or let of any perfon: (2) It may therefore pleafe your highnefs of your moft abundant grace, with the affent of thie lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons, in this prefent parliament aflembled, and by authority of the fame, in confideration of the premiffes, and alfo for that the faid cuftom is not grounded upon any law, to ordain, enaft, and eftablifh. That John Trevethen, Richard Welles, Oliver Leader, John Croke, William Jeffon, and John Lemfey, now being in the office of the fix clerks of the chancery, and every of them, and all other which in time to come shall be in the fame office, and every of them, may and do take wives and marry at their liberty, after the laws of holy church * (3) and that they, and every of them fo married, may have, hold, and enjoy their faid office of fix clerks, in as ample, large, and like manner, as they did or (hould do before the faid efpoufals, or as if they had never been married, the faid cuftom, or any other cuftom or ordinance heretofore had or made to the contrary notwithstanding.

III.	Provided alway. That by any thing in this a<ft contained, the mafter of the rolls for the time being be not prejudiced cither in the giving and difpofition of the faid offices from time to time, as hath been heretofore accuftomed, the forfeiture of that office by reafon of marriage 6nly except. And that the faid officers which now be, and hereafter shall be, do give fuch attendance unto the faid mafter of the rolls for the time being, as heretofore in the faid offices hath been accuftomed,

CAP. X.

The penalty for unlawful hunting the bare.

FORASMUCH as our sovereign lord the King, and other noblemen of this realm ^England’, before this time have vfed and exercifed the game of hunting of the hare for their difport and pleafure* which game is now decayed, and almojl utterly deftroyed, for that divers perfrns in divers parts of this realm* by reajon of the tracing in fnow, have killed and defrayed* and daily do kill ana dejlroy the fame hares, by x, xij, or xvi, upon one day, to the difbleafure of our faid fivereign lord the King, and other noblemen of this his realm.	(2)	The penalty

Wherefore be it enabled by our faid sovereign lord, by the lords spiritual and temporal, and by the commons, in this pre- Jh/fnow.11* fent parliament aflembled, and by authority of the fame. That no person or perfons, of what eftate, degree, or condition they be, jfirom henceforth trace, deftroy, and kill any hare in the fnow with anv dog, bitch, bow, nor otherwife. ^3) And that juftices of the juftices or peace within every (hire, at every (eflions of the peace and peace, and Rewards of leets, shall have full authority and power Regard* in to enquire of fuch offenders; (4) and after fuch inquifitions	^

found, the faid juftices of the peace and Rewards of leets, for puJJi^thc'of-every hare fo killed, shall cefs upon every fuch offender vi. s. fenders, viij. d. to be forfeited to our faid sovereign lord, that shall be fo founden by the juftices of peace in their feffions, (5) and the 1 Jac. 1. c. 17. forfeitqre found in every leet to be to the lord of the leet.

CAP. XII.

What coiners Jhall do that make money at airy mint within

England.

COINERS that fhall make any money at any mint, shall coin part thereof half-angels, groats, and (mall money. The print of the farthing. The tenth part of money coined for any person shall be paid in half-pence and farthings. This ad not to affed the coiners of York, Durefme, or Canterbury.

CAP. VI.

Where mortuaries ought to be paid,for wbat perfons, and bow much \ and in what cafe none is due.

chanced and receiving, as well

for the greatnefs and value of the fame, which ^ as hath lately been taken, is thought over-excejjive to the poor people and other perfons of this realm, (2)0$ alfo for that fuch mortuaries or corfe prefents have been demanded and levied, for fuch as at the time of their death have had no property in any goods or chattels, and many times for travelling and wayfaring men, in the places where they have fortuned to die;

(3)	to the intent that all doubt, contention, and incertainty herein may be removed, and as well the generality of the King's people therein re-medied, as alfo of the parfons, vicars, parijh priefts, curates, and other having interejl in fuch mortuaries and corfe prefents indifferently provided for:

II.	Be it therefore enadfed, ordained, and eftablifhed by the King our sovereign lord, and the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons of this parliament afiembled, and by authority of the fame, That from the first day of April, in the year of our Lord God M.D.XXX. no parfon, vicar, curate, nor parilh prieft, ne any other fpiritual perfon, nor their fer-mors, bailiffs, nor leilees, shall take, receive, or demand of any person or perfons within this realm, for any person or perfons dying within the fame, any manner mortuary or corfe prefent, ne any lum or fums of money, ne any other thing for the fame, more than is hereafter mentioned; (2) ne alfo shall convent or call any person or perfons before any judge fpiritual, for the recovery of any fuch mortuaries or corfe prefents, or any other thing for the lame, more than is hereafter mentioned, (3) upon pain to forfeit for every time fo demanding, receiving, taking, or conventing, or calling any fuch person or perfons before any fpiritual judge, fo much in value as they fhall take above the fum limited by this aGt, and over that, xl. s. to the party grieved contrary to this a<5t j (4) for the which forfeiture the party fo grieved contrary to this a&, fhall have an adlion of debt, by writ, bill, plaint, or information in any of the King’s courts, wherein no wager of law, efloin, nor protedtion fhall be allowed*

CAP. XV.

Fermors Jhall enjoy their leafes against recoveries by feigned titles,

WHERE afore this time divers perfons have made Uafes of their manorsy landsy tekementSy and other hereditamentSy fometime by their indentures and fametime without writingSy to other perfons for term of yearsf taking of them great fines for the incomes of the fame leafes; and after the fame leafors9 their heirsy or ajfignsy have eaufed and fufferea recoveries to be had againjl them in the court of our fovcretgn lord the Kingy and in other lords courtSy upon feigned and untrue titlesy by craft or covin to put the fame termers from their J'aid terms \ (2) and after fuch recoveries hady the fame rtcovereeiy by rcafon of fuch recoveries and judgmentSy have entered into the fame manor Sy landsy tenements y and other hereditaments fo to firm letteny and thereof have expulfed the faid fermersy contrary to their faid leaf esy covenant Sy and agreements \ (3) and bccaufc it was doubted to feme perfonsy whether the faid termers might falfify fueh recoveries, or not:

And that none of the faidfir angers artificers, or handieraftf men, born out of our Jaid sovereign lord his obeifance, as well deni-zens, as no denizens, should qffemble in any company, fellowjhip, con* gregation, or conventicle, but only in the common-hall of their crafts, with our faid sovereign lord bis fubjeft s which be of the companies of their0faid craft or crafts, at fuch time as they should be commanded and warned by the faid mafiers and wardens of their faid craft or crafts, and at none other place and time, or in any other manner, upon the pain afore exprejfed: as by the faid decree Jbcwed and exemplified, and hereunto annexed, under our faid sovereign lord the King his great feal, more plainly, and at large, it may and doth appear.

VII.	That for the common wealth abovesaid, it may be enabled by the King our sovereign lord, the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons in this prefent parliament aflemb^ led, an<} by the authority of the fame. CAP. XVIII.

No person shall (hip, load, or unload any goods, to be fold into or from any (hip at any place within the river of Tine, between the places called Sparhawk and , but only at the town of Newcajlle. II.	Be it therefore enadted, eftablifhed, and ordained by authority of this prefent parliament. That wherefoever any manner lands, tenements, and other hereditaments be holden of any manner person or perfons, by rents* cuftoms, or fer-vices, that if the lord, of whom any fuch manner lands, tenements, or hereditaments be fo holden, diftrain upon the fame manors, lands, or tenements, for any fuch rents, cuftoms, or fer-vices, and replevin thereof be fued, that the lord of whom the fame lands, tenements, or hereditaments be fo holden, may'avow, or his bailiff or fervant make conifance, or juftify, for taking of the fgid diftrefles upon the fame lands, tenements, or hereditaments fo holden, as in lands or tenements within his fee or feig-niory, (2) alledging in the laid avowry, conifance and juftification, the fame manors, lands, and tenements to be holden of him, without naming of any person certain to be tenant of the fame, and without making any avowry, juftificationy or conifance upon any person certain; (3) and likewife the lord, baily, or fervant to make avowry, juftification, or conhanee in like manner and form upon every writ fued of fecond deliverance. •

III.	And alfo be it enadted by the faid authority, That evesy avowant, and every other person or perfons that make any fuch avowry, juftification, or conifance, as baily or fervant to any person or perfons in any replegiare, or fecond deliverance, for rents, cuftoms, fervices, or for damage fefant, or other rent or rents, upon any diftrefs taken in any lands or tenements, if the fame avowry, conifance, or juftification be found for them, or the plaintiffs in the fame be npnfuit, or otherwife barred, that then they shall recover their damages and cofts against the faid plaintiffs, as the fame plaintiffs (hould have done or had, if they had recovered in the replegiare, or fecond deliverance found against the faid defendants.

IV.	And be it alfo ordained. That the faid plaintiffs and defendants in the faid writs of replegiare, or writs of fecond deliverance, and in every of them, shall have like pleas, and like aid-prayers in all fuen avowries, conifances, and joffifications (pleas of difclaimet* only except) as they might have had before the making of this adt, and as though the faid avowry, c6ni-fance, or juftification had been made after the due order of the common law.

V.	And it is further enadted by the faid authority, That all fuch perfons as by the order of the common law may lawfully join to the plaintiffs or defendants in the faid writs of replegiart, or fecond deliverance, a$ well without’ procefs as by procefc, shall from henceforth join unto the faid plaintiffs or defendant, as well without procefs as by proceis, and to have like pleas, and like advantages in all things (difclaimer only except) as they might have done by the order of the common law before the making of this adL

CAP. X.

An aft concerning outlandi/h people, calling tbemfelvds Egyptians.

FORASMUCH as before this time divers and many outlandi/h Enforced by people calling themfelves Egyptians, ufmg no craft nor feat of i&*Ph.&M. merchandife, have come into this realm, and gone from /hire to Jhire, c* ( and place to place in great company, and ufed great, fubtily and crafty * 5 means to deceive the people, bearing them in handy that they by palmejlry could, tell men's and women's fortunes, and fo many times by craft and fubtilty have deceived the people of their money, and alfo have committed many heinous felonies and robberies, to the great hurt and deceit of the people that they have come among:

. II. Be it therefore by the King our sovereign lord, the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons, in this prefent parliament affembled, and by the authority of the fame, ordained, eftablifhed, and ena&ed, That from henceforth no fuch person be fuffered to come within this the King’s realm; and if they do, then they and every of them fo doing, shall forfeit to the King our sovereign lord all their goods and chattels, and them to be commanded to avoid the realm within fifteen days next after the commandment, upon pain of imprifonment; and it shall be lawful to every (heriff, juftice of peace, and efcheator, to feifc to the ufe of our sovereign lord, his heirs and fucceflors, all fuch goods as they or any of them shall have, and thereof to make account to our faid sovereign lord in his exchequer; and if it shall happen any fuch ftranger hereafter to commit within this realm any murder, robbery, or any other felony, and thereof be indi&ed, and arraigned, and to plead not guilty, or any other plea triable by the country, that then the inqueft that shall pafs between the king and any fuch party, shall be altogether of Englijhmeny albeit that the party fo indicted pray Medietatem lingua y according to the ftatute of Anno 8 Henrici VI. or any other ftatute thereof made.

III.	Provided alway. That the Egyptians now being in this realm, have monition to depart within fixteen days after proclamation of this ftatute among them shall be made, upon pain of imprifonment, and forfeiture of their goods and chattels ; and if they then fo depart, that then they shall not forfeit their goods nor any part thereof, this prefent ftatute notwithstanding.

IV.	Provided alway, That every fuch person or perfon?, which can prove by two credible penons, before the fame party that feifeth fuch money, goods, or chattels, of the fame Egypr tianSy that any part of the (ame goods, money, or chattels, were craftily or felonioufty taken or ftolen from him, shall be incoiv-tinent reftored unto the fame goods, money, or chattels, whereof he maketh fuch proof beiore the fame party, that fo feifeth

CAP. XIV.

For abjurations and sanctuaries.

THE King our sovereign lord conjidering, that many of his fub~ jefts heretofore for their offences and merits, have been put i§ execution of death by tne laws of this realm, and many other commitr ting like offences^ for tuition of their HveSy have fed and reforted to churches, and other hallowed places within this realm, and there be-ingy have abjured the realm before the King's coroners of the famt\ (2) divers of which men (fo abjuring) have been known to be very expert mariners, and many other have been feen9 to be very able and apt men for the wars, and defence of this realmy fo that by the one mean* and the other, the (Irengtn and power of this realm is greatly minified. (3) And divers of the faid perfons which heretofore have abjured this realmy being by reafon of their abjurations in outward realms and countrieSy have not only procured many men of the fame to the exercife and praftife of archery, aud have injlrufled them in the feat and knowledge thereofy to the great increafe and fortifications of the fame outward realms and countrieSy but alfo the fame abjured per fens have difclofed their knowledges of the commodities and fecrets of this realm, to no little damage and prejudice of the fame: (4) the King's high-nrfs therefore daily Jludying and deviftng to provide for the jafeguard of this his realmy and of his fubjeftSy albeit they be trangrejfors of his lawsyfo that the incommodities infuing upon fuch abjurations to be preferved to the befl effect as far as Jhall pleafe God to give them grace; hath ordained and ena&ed by authority of this prefent parliament. An aft concerning convifts in petit treafon, murder, &c.

CAP. IT.

An aSt concerning new making of barrels, kilderkins> and other vejfelu

WHERE the aU+brewers and beer-brewers of this realm of England have ufed, and daily do ufe, for their own fingular hurt) profit, and gain , to make in their cum houfes their barrels, /h7-derkins, and firkins, of much lefs quantity, content, rate, and affize than they ought to be, to the great hurt, prejudice, and damage of the King's liege people, and contrary to divers afts, fiatutes, ancient lotus and cujloms heretofore made, had, and ufed, and to the definition of the poor craft or myfiery of coopers: (2) For reformation whereof, be it ena&ed by the King our sovereign lord, the lords fpi- No brewer of ritual and temporal, and the commons, in this prefent par-foment aflembled, and by authority of the feme, That no myft™ ^ a beer-brewer nor ale-brewer, that (hail brew to folc beer or ale, coopery nor shall from henceforth occupy by hknfelf, nor by any other to make any bar-his ufe, in his houfe, nor elfewhere, the myftery or craft of rcis> &c* coopers, nor make any barrels, kilderkins, firkins, or other vends, by himfelf, nor by his or their own fcrvants, whereby they shall put their beer or ale to fide; (3) but that all fuen barrels, kilderkins, and other veflels of wood, wherewith they shall put their beer or ale to fide, shall from henceforth be made and marked according as hereafter shall beexpreffed, by the common artificers of coopers, exercifed and pra&ifed in the (aid occupation, upon pain to forfeit and pay for every fuch barrel, kilderkin, firkin, or other veflel hereafter to be made contrary to the tenor of this a<5t, three (hillings four pence.

II.	And be it alfo ena&ed, Tnat every artificer of the craft v- .	.

or myftery of coopers, that will exercife or pnuftife to make ^nd any of the faid veflfels for beer or ale to be put to (ale, shall make be made of the fame veflels, and every of them, of good and feafonable feafonable wood, and put his proper mark upon every of them ; (2) and woo£r?nd that every barrel for beer shall contain xxxvi. gallons, every content* kilderkin for beer xviij. gallons, and every firkin for beer ix. of barrels, kil-gallons, of the King*s ftandard gallon; (3) and that every bar- derkins, See. rel for ale shall contain xxxij. gallons, every kilderkin tor ale *vi. gallons, and every firkin for ale viij. gallons, of the King’s ftandard gallon; fo that they shall be of good and juft measure, or elfe above, and not under, (4) And that no cooper shall make any other veflel for beer or ale, to be fold within this realm, of any greater or lefler number of gallons than is abovesaid, unlefs he mall caufe to be marked upon every fiich veflel that he shall fo make of greater or lefler number of gallons, the true and certain numbef of as many gallons as every fuch other veflel shall contain, to the intent that every person may know the content thereof.

V. VI. half-barrel empty to be in weight xiij. pound, and not above, and to hold and contain xvi. gallons, or above; and every firkin empty to weigh vi. pounds and a half, and not above, and to hold and contain viii. gallons, or above, upon pain of forfeiture for every fiich barrel, half-barrel, firkin, or other veflel hereafter to be made, had, or ufed contrary to this a eft, iii. s. iv. d.

VII. And alfo be it enaded by the authority aforefaid. CAP. XIII.

An act for trial of murders in cities and towns.

FORASMUCH as trials in murders and felonies in cities, boroughs, and towns corporate within this realm, having authority to proceed in the deliverance of fuch offenders, oftentimes deferred and delayed, by reafon of challenge offuch offenders for lack of fufficiency of freehold, to the great hindrance of jujlice: (2) It may therefore be enabled by authority of this prefent parliament, Trial of fc-That every person and perfons* being the King’s natural fub- lons m corP°-jedl born, which either by the name of a citizen, or of a free- ^U^by man, or any other name, doth enjoy and ufe the liberties and men worth xl. privileges of any city, borough, or town corporate, where he li. in goods, dwelleth and maketh his abode, being worth in moveable goods and fubftanceto the clear value of forty pounds, be from henceforth admitted in trial of murders and felonies in every feflions and gaol-delivery, to be kept and holden in and for the liberty of fuch cities, boroughs, and towns corporate, albeit they have no freehold * any a<ft, ftatute, ufe, cuftom, or ordinance to the contrary hereof notwithstanding.

II. Provided alway. That this a6t do not extend, in any manner of wife, to any knight or efquire, dwelling, abiding, or reforting in or to any fuch city, town, or borough corporate, any thing in the fame a<fr mentioned or declared to the contrary hereof notwithstanding.

Procefs of outlawry to lie in aftions, on 5 Rich. 2. and in covenant and annuity.

FORASMUCH as there is great delay in aftions of trefpafs brought upon the Jlatute of Richard the Second, made in the fifth year of his reign, againfi them that make entries into any lands or tenements where their entry is not given by the law, and alfo in, actions of annuity, and aftions of covenant, becaufe there lieth no procefs of outlawry in fuch nature of aftions: (2) For reformation Like procefs to whereof, it may pleafe the King’s highnefs, by the advice of the bc had in. lords spiritual and temporal, and the commbns, in this prefent parliament affembled, and by authority of the fame, to ordain covenant, as and ena<5}, That like procefs be had hereafter in every a<ftion in an a&ion from hericeforth to be brought upon the faid ftatute of Anno of debt. quinto, as is in a common action of trefpafs at the common law, 5 R* *•ftat- *• (3) and that alfo like procefs be had in every writ of annuity bV. C AP. XV.

An ait that the plaintiff, being nonfuited, Jhall yield damages to, the defendants in aiiions perfonal, by the diferetion of the juftices.

BE it enacted by the King our sovereign lord, and the lords spiritual and temporal, and the commons,. in this ptrefeot parliament aflembled, and by authority of the fame. CAP. X.

For the dejlruRion of crows and rooks.

FORASMUCH j; innumerable number of rooks, crows and choughs do daily breed, and increafe throughout this realm, which rooks, crows and choughs, do yearly devour and confume a wonderful and marvellous great quantity of corn and grain of all kinds, that is to wit, as well in the jowing of the fame com and grain, as alfo at the ripening and kcrnelling of the fame, and over that a marvellous ief-truliion, and decay of the covertures of thatched houfes, bams, reeks, flacks and other fuch like: (2) fo that if the faid crows, rooks and choughs should be fuffered to breed and continue% as they have been in certain years paft, they will undoubtedly be the caufe of the great dcjlruftion and confumption of a great part of the corn ana grain which hereafter Jhall be fown throughout this realm, to the great prejudice, damage and undoing of the great number of all the tillers, hufbands and J'owers of the earth within the fame.

II. For remedy whereof, be it enabled by the authority of this prefent parliament, That every person and perfons, as well fpi-ritual as temporal, having, keeping, holding and inhabiting in any manors, meafes, lands or tenements in their own manurance and occupation of any eftate of inheritance, or for term of life, or foryears, or at will, or by copy of court-roll, or otherwife in poflemon or ufe, shall hereafter do, or caufe to be done, as much as in him or them reafonably shall or may be, to kill and utterly deftroy all manner of choughs, crows, rooks, coming, abiding, breeding or haunting within or upon any the faid manors, meafes, lands or tenements which he or they shall inhabit and dwell upon, and have in their manurance and occupation, as is aforefaid, (2) upon pain of a grievous amerciament, to be let and affeffed as hereafter shall be exprefled: that is to fay, that if any offence be done contrary to the ftatute, by any person or perfons inhabited within the limits of the leets, lawdays, rapes or court barons of any lords having fuch courts, that then upon a prefentment thereof made before the Reward of fuch leets, lawdays, rapes or courts, the Rewards with two of the presenters, (by the Reward and prefenters to be named) shall auefs and fet for every default prefented to be done contrary to this a<5l, fuch amerciament as to them shall feem reafonable and convenient, after the quantity of the offence, (3) the faid amerciament to be to the ufe of the lord, or lords of the leets, law-days, rapes or courts where the faid offence shall be done and prefented, to be levied by diftrefs of the goods and chattels of the offender or offenders, like as other amerciaments for common annoyances (prefented in leets) have been accuftomed to be levied.

(4)	And if the offence be done contrary to this ftatute by any person or perfons, which shall dwell and have the manurance of and in fuch manors, meafes, lands, tenements or hereditaments, whereunto fuch leets, lawdays, rapes and courts do not belong, or by reafon whereof any fuch courts be not holden :

III.	And farther be it enabled by the authority aforefaid. That in every parilh, townlhip, hamlet, borough or village within this realm, wherein is at leaft ten houftiolds inhabited, the tenants and inhabitants thereof shall before the feaft of St. Michael the archangel next, and fo during ten years next enfu-ing the faid feaft, at their own proper cofts, charges and ex-pences, provide, make or caufe to be made one net, commonly called a net to take choughs, crows, and rooks, with all things requifite or belonging to the fame, (2) and the (aid net fo made or caufed to be made, shall keep, preferve and renew, as often as shall need: and with and after a (hrap made with chaff and other things meet for that purpofe, shall lay or caufe to be laid, at fuch time or times in the year, as are convenient for deftruc-tion of fuch choughs, rooks and crows, and in fuch place and places as shall be thought expedient to take the faid choughs, crows and rooks, (3) upon pain to forfeit ten (hillings, the one moiety thereof to be to our sovereign lord the King, and the other moiety to the lord or lords of the fame courts, leets, law-days or rapes, where any fuch net shall be lacking, and not made, and put in execution according to this a<ft, (4) to be levied of the faid tenants and inhabitants of the faid pari(h, townfhip, hamlet, borough or village, where any fuch net shall be lacking, and not put in ure and execution as is aforefaid. (5) And that every fuch net with all things requifite thereunto, shall one time in tne year, at the leaft, be presented in the court baron, leet, rape or lawday, before the fteward of the fame court, leet, rape or lawday, whereunto the faid tenants and inhabitants shall be bounden to fue, and appear, to be viewed, whether the fame be Efficiently repaired or not, for the forefaid purpofe: (6) So that by the advice of the fteward, tenants and inhabitants of the faid court baron, leet, rape or lawday, where any fuch net shall be neceffary to be ufed, a fure way and ordinance may be devifed for the reparation, continuance and putting in execution of the faid net at times and places convenient, as is aforefaid. (7) And that fuch ordinances as shall be devifed and made by tne fteward, tenants and inhabitants of and within the faid leets, lawdays, rapes and courts, or by the mod part of them, to and for the deftrultion of the faid rooks, crows and choughs, shall (land good and effectual, and be put in due execution, according to the tenor thereof.

CAP. nr.

For jurors in Wales.

CAP. VI.

The bill for the incteafe of horfes.

THE King ourfovereign lord continually fludying for the advance* ment, augmentation and increafe of the publicl weal of this hit calm,, calling to his mojl gracious memory the great decay of the generation and breeding of goody and fwift and firong horfes, which eretofore have been bred in this realm^ to the great defence^ profit nd common commodity of the fame; and now remembring that like reed of horfes is fore diminifbed and decayed, the occafion whereof is bought to proceed, for that in many and mojl places of this realms rnmonly little horfes and nags of f mall fiature and value be fuffered ? depqflure, and alfo to cover mares and fillies of very fmallJlature, y reaton whereof the breed of good and ftrong horfes of this realm is gw lately diminijhed, altered and decayed, and farther is like to decay% ffpeedy remedy be not fooner provided in that behalf II. CAP. XI.

For clerks of the fignet.

CAP. XXIV.

An aB for recontinuing liberties in the crown.

WHERE divers of the mojl ancient prerogatives and authorities of jujiice, appertaining to the imperial crown of this realty have been fevered and taken from the fame by fundry gifts of the King's moft noble progenitors, Kings of this realmy to the great diminution and detriment of the royal efate of the famey and to the hindrance and great delay of jujlice ; (2) for reformation whereof, be it enadled by authority of this prefent parliament. That no person or perfons, of what eftate or degree foever they be, from the first day of Julyy which shall be in the year of our Lord God 1536, shall have any power or authority to pardon or remit any treafons, murders, manflaughters, or any kinds of felonies, whatfoever they be; (3) nor any acceflaries to any treafons, murders, manflaughters or felonies; (4) or any outlawries for any fuch offences afore rehearfed, committed, perpetrated, done or divulged, or hereafter to be committed, done or divulged, by or against any person or perfons in any part of this realm, IValeSy or the marches of the fame ; (5) but that the King’s highnefs, his heirs and fucceflors. CAP. XXV,

AH governors of (hires, cities, towhs, hundreds, hamlets and parifhes, shall find and keep evriry aged, poor and impotent perfon, which was born of dwelt three years within the fame limit, by Way of voluntary and charitable alms in evety of the fame cities and parifhes, (sit. with fuch convenient aims as shall be thought meet by their diferebon, fo as none of them

(hall be compelled to go. openly in begging. And aHb fttdl compel every fturdy vagabond to be kept in continual labour. (2) Children under fourteen years ot age, and above five, that live in idlenefs, and be taken begging, may be put to fervice by the governors of cities, towns, &c. to hnfbandry, or other crafts or labours. (3) A valiant beggar, or fhirdy vagabond, shall at the first time be whipped, and lent to the place where he was bom or laft dwelled by the (pace of three years, there to get his living ; and if he continue his rogutfh life, he shall have the upper part of the griftlfc of his right ear cut off; and if after that he be taken wandering in idlenefe, or doth not apply to his labour, or is not in fervice with any mailer, he shall be adjudged and executed as a felon. (4) No person shall make any open or common dole, nor shall give any money in alms, but to the common boxes, and common gatherings in every parifh, upon pain to forfeit ten times fo much as shall be given. (5) There shall be no playing at unlawful games.

Concerning the laws to be ufed in Wales.

¥he bill for non-refidcnce of fpiritual men and their benefices.

For prices of wines.

BE it enafted by authority of this prefent parliament. That no person or perfons shall fell any Gafcoin, Guyen or French wines, above viij. d. the gallon, that is to fay, a peny the pint, two-pence the quart, four-pence the pottle, and eight-pence the gallon, upon pain of forfeiture for every pint to be fold above the laid price, iv. d. and for every quart fold above the faid price, viij. d. and for every pottle fo fold above the faid price, xij. d. and for every gallon fo fold above the faid price afore limited, \\. s. HENRY the Eighth, by the grace of God King of Eng: ' land, and of France, defender of the faith, lord of Ireland, and in earth fupreme head immediately under Cbrift <f the church of England, to the honour of Almighty God, confervation of the true do ftrine of Cbrifts religion, and for the concord, quiet and wealth of this bis realm, arid fubjeBs of the fame, held bis moft high court of parliament, begun at Weftminfter the twenty-eighth day of April and there continued till the twenty-eighth day of June, the one and thirtieth year of his moft noble and viBorious rexgny wherein were eftabUJhed tbefeaBs following.

CAP. VIII.

The King for the time being, with the advice of his council, or the more part of them, may set forth proclamations under such penalties and pains as to him and them shall seem necessary, which shall be observed as though they were made by act of parliament; but this shall not be prejudicial to any person’s inheritance, offices, liberties, goods, chattels or life;

[34. H. 8. c. s3. REP. by 1 Ed.]	
and whosoever shall willingly offend any article contained in the said proclamations, shall pay such forfeitures, or be so long imprisoned, as shall be expressed in the said proclamations; and if any offending will depart the realm, to the intent he will not answer his said offence, he shall be adjudged a traitor.

That in all trials of treafons by peers of this realm, if any of the peers that shall be called hereafter to be triours of fuch treafons, shall happen to have any of the offices aforefaid, that then they, having luch offices, shall fit and be placed according to their offices, above all the other peers that shall be called to fuch trials, in manner and form as is above mentioned and re-r hearfed.

X.	And it is alfo enabled by authority aforefaid. That as well in aH parliaments, as in the (tar-chamber, and in all pther aflemblies and conferences of council, the lord chancellor, the lord treafuer, the lord prefident, the lord privy feal, the great chamberlain, the conftable, the marlhal, the lord admiral, the grand mailer or lord fteward, the King’s chamberlain, and the (Ling’s chief fecretary, shall fit and be placed in fuch order and fafnion as is above rehearfed, and not in any other place, by authority of this prefent adt.

CAP. XL

The authority given to the King by the ftatute of 28 H. c. 3. to allot the towns in IVales, continued for three years.

CAP. XII.

It shall be felony to take, in the King’s ground, any egg or bird of any faulcon, gofhawk or laner, out of the neft; or to find or take up any iaulcon, jerfoulcon, jerkin, facer or facerit, golhawk, laricr or lanerite, of the King’s, and having on it the King’s arms and verviles, and do not within twelve days bring or fend the'fame to the mafter of the King’s hawks, or to one of his faulconers, or t6 the chief of the (hire; (2) or between the rifing of the fun, and fetting of the fame, with his face hid or covered with hood or vifert, or painted, or difguifed,. to the intent he would not be known, to enter into anyTorefi, chafe or park of the King’s, Queen’s, prince's, or any of the King’s* children, or into any other ground of either of theirs indofed with wall or pale, ordained for the keeping of deer, to the intent to deal any of them, or to drive

CAP. XtV.

An all for abolifhing of diverfty of opinions in certain articles concerning cbrijlian religion.
